factoid: The infantry officer with a bandaged cheek asked Túshin, "You don’t mind your honor?"
The infantry officer said, "I’ve lost my company, your honor. I don’t know where... such bad luck!"
The infantry officer approached the bonfire.
The infantry officer asked Túshin to move the guns a trifle to let a wagon go past.
Two soldiers rushed to the campfire after the infantry officer had gone.
The two soldiers were quarreling and fighting desperately.
Each of the two soldiers was trying to snatch a boot from the other.
One soldier shouted, "You picked it up?... I dare say! You’re very smart!"
A thin, pale soldier with a neck bandaged with a bloodstained leg band came up.
The thin, pale soldier asked the artillerymen for water in angry tones.
The thin, pale soldier said, "Must one die like a dog?"
Túshin told the soldiers to give the thin, pale soldier some water.
A cheerful soldier ran up and begged for a little fire for the infantry.
The cheerful soldier said, "A nice little hot torch for the infantry! Good luck to you, fellow countrymen. Thanks for the fire—we’ll return it with interest."
The cheerful soldier carried away a glowing stick into darkness.
Four soldiers carrying something heavy on a cloak passed by the fire.
One of the four soldiers stumbled.
One soldier snarled, "Who the devil has put the logs on the road?"
Another soldier said, "He’s dead—why carry him?"
Another soldier said, "Shut up!"
The four soldiers disappeared into darkness with their load.
Túshin asked Rostóv in a whisper, "Still aching?"
Rostóv answered, "Yes."
A gunner said, "Your honor, you’re wanted by the general. He is in the hut here."
Túshin replied, "Coming, friend."
Túshin rose, buttoned his greatcoat, pulled it straight, and walked away from the fire.
Prince Bagratión sat in a hut prepared for him and ate dinner with commanding officers.
The little old man with half-closed eyes greedily gnawed a mutton bone.
The general who had served blamelessly for twenty-two years was flushed by a glass of vodka and the dinner.
The staff officer with the signet ring was present.
Zherkóv was uneasily glancing at them all.
Prince Andrew was pale, with compressed lips and feverishly glittering eyes.
A standard captured from the French stood in a corner of the hut.
The accountant with a naïve face was feeling the standard’s texture, shaking his head in perplexity.
The accountant was hungry and looked on at a dinner where there was no place for him.
A French colonel had been taken prisoner by our dragoons and was in the next hut.
Our officers flocked in to look at the French colonel.
Prince Bagratión thanked the individual commanders and inquired into details of the action and our losses.
The general whose regiment had been inspected at Braunau withdrew from the wood as soon as the action began.
The general mustered the men who were woodcutting.
The general allowed the French to pass him.
The general made a bayonet charge with two battalions.
The general broke up the French troops.

The general said, "When I saw that their first battalion was disorganized, I stopped in the road and thought: ‘I’ll let them come on and will meet them with the fire of the whole battalion’—and that’s what I did."
The general had wished to do this and was so sorry he had not managed to do it.
The general imagined it as if it had really happened.
The general wondered if it might have really been so.
The general remembered Dólokhov’s conversation with Kutúzov and his last interview with the gentleman-ranker.

The general said, "By the way, your excellency, I should inform you that Private Dólokhov, who was reduced to the ranks, took a French officer prisoner in my presence and particularly distinguished himself."
Zherkóv chimed in, looking uneasily around.
Zherkóv said, "I saw the Pávlograd hussars attack there, your excellency."
Zherkóv had not seen the hussars that day but had heard about them from an infantry officer.
Zherkóv said, "They broke up two squares, your excellency."
